title: Writing
content: Forthcoming When Good Intentions Fail How Institutions Quietly Transfer Burden Back Cover Values-driven institutions often look humane on the surface: careful language, collaborative norms, and a shared sense of mission. But when roles, authority, and decision-making stay unfinished, responsibility doesn‚Äôt disappear. It relocates into ambiguity, informal expectations, and the people most willing to carry the load. Over time, ‚Äúbeing reliable‚Äù becomes a job requirement. Exhaustion becomes normal. And the system keeps functioning precisely because someone keeps compensating. When Good Intentions Fail names the pattern clearly‚Äîwithout drama‚Äîand gives readers a way to recognize where the burden went, why it landed there, and how to stop mistaking personal strain for personal failure. Excerpt Most institutions begin with language‚Äîmission statements, values decks, guiding principles. Early on, those words attract people who care and create a sense of shared purpose. But eventually, values have to become structure: roles, authority, process, and protection. When that translation never fully happens, values start doing work they were never designed to do. ‚ÄúValues can guide decisions. They cannot carry them.‚Äù Early Reader Feedback ‚ÄúBravo!
